elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

Tppz (2,3,5,6-tetrakis(2-pyridyl)pyrazine) complexes [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF6]2.acetylacetone (bpy=2,2'-bipyridine) and [{CdCl2}2(μ-tppz)].ethylene glycol have been synthesized and characterized. Solid state structures of both complexes have been determined by single-crystal X-ray crystallography. The structural determination shows that the dinuclear Cd(II) complex, [{CdCl2}2(μ-tppz)], is a 1D coordination polymer. An ORTEP drawing of [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF6]2.acetylacetone shows that the coordination geometry around the Rh(III) is a distorted octahedron.

<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">Tppz (2,3,5,6-tetrakis(2-pyridyl)pyrazine) complexes [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>.acetylacetone (bpy<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2,2′-bipyridine) and [{CdCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-tppz)].ethylene glycol have been synthesized and characterized by elemental analyses, IR, <ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>H NMR, cyclic voltammetry, photoluminescence and electronic spectral studies. Solid state structures of both complexes have been determined by single-crystal X-ray crystallography. The structural determination shows that the dinuclear Cd(II) complex, [{CdCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-tppz)], is a 1D coordination polymer. An ORTEP drawing of [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>.acetylacetone shows that the coordination geometry around the Rh(III) center is a distorted octahedron. [{CdCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-tppz)] displays intraligand <ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>(π–π<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup>) fluorescence and can potentially serve as a photoactive material. For the mononuclear Rh(III) complex, only a two-electron reduction process occurs at the metal with the elimination of Cl<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligand. The emission of this complex is assigned as πd<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup> phosphorescence.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Tppz (2,3,5,6-tetrakis(2-pyridyl)pyrazine) complexes [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF6]2.acetylacetone (bpy=2,2'-bipyridine) and [{CdCl2}2(μ-tppz)].ethylene glycol have been synthesized and characterized by elemental analyses, IR, 1H NMR, cyclic voltammetry, photoluminescence and electronic spectral studies. Solid state structures of both complexes have been determined by single-crystal X-ray crystallography. The structural determination shows that the dinuclear Cd(II) complex, [{CdCl2}2(μ-tppz)], is a 1D coordination polymer. An ORTEP drawing of [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF6]2.acetylacetone shows that the coordination geometry around the Rh(III) center is a distorted octahedron. [{CdCl2}2(μ-tppz)] displays intraligand 1(π-π∗) fluorescence and can potentially serve as a photoactive material. For the mononuclear Rh(III) complex, only a two-electron reduction process occurs at the metal with the elimination of Cl- ligand. The emission of this complex is assigned as πd∗ phosphorescence.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Tridentate ligands offer the possibility of controlling the stereochemistry of octahedral metal complexes. When a symmetric tridentate ligand is coordinated to a metal ion, there is only one possible stereoisomer. If symmetric tridentate bridging ligands are used in the construction of multimetallic systems, there is only one possible isomer for the whole multimetallic system. Furthermore, the whole complex is a linear, rod-like system. This fixes the metal–metal distance, which is essential in understanding energy and electron transfer. Tridentate bridged systems therefore offer many advantages over bidentate bridged systems where the metal–metal distance and photophysical properties can vary depending on the coordination of the ligands. Even though tridentate ligands offer advantages in transition metal complexes, there has been less work done with tridentate ligands than with bidentate ligands .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Tridentate ligands offer the possibility of controlling the stereochemistry of octahedral metal complexes. When a symmetric tridentate ligand is coordinated to a metal ion, there is only one possible stereoisomer. If symmetric tridentate bridging ligands are used in the construction of multimetallic systems, there is only one possible isomer for the whole multimetallic system. Furthermore, the whole complex is a linear, rod-like system. This fixes the metal-metal distance, which is essential in understanding energy and electron transfer. Tridentate bridged systems therefore offer many advantages over bidentate bridged systems where the metal-metal distance and photophysical properties can vary depending on the coordination of the ligands. Even though tridentate ligands offer advantages in transition metal complexes, there has been less work done with tridentate ligands than with bidentate ligands .

<ce:float-anchor refid="sch1"></ce:float-anchor>). The first attempts of complex formation between tppz and transition metal ions provided molecular species with 1:1 and 1:2 metal ions to tppz ligand molar ratios .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Many different types of polyazine tridentate bridging ligands have been investigated . In 1959, Goodwin and Lions  first reported a method for the synthesis of 2,3,5,6-tetrakis(2-pyridyl)pyrazine (tppz) ( ). The first attempts of complex formation between tppz and transition metal ions provided molecular species with 1:1 and 1:2 metal ions to tppz ligand molar ratios .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">A number of researchers have investigated transition metal complexes of tppz because of its application to supramolecular materials with desirable photophysical or magnetic properties , sensors , molecular wires , mixed-metal supramolecular compounds , coordination polymers , biochemical and DNA binding properties , and supramolecular films .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: A number of researchers have investigated transition metal complexes of tppz because of its application to supramolecular materials with desirable photophysical or magnetic properties , sensors , molecular wires , mixed-metal supramolecular compounds , coordination polymers , biochemical and DNA binding properties , and supramolecular films .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">At this point in time, seven coordination modes of metal complexes with tppz ligand are known . The tppz bridged bimetallic complexes [{CuCl}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-tppz)][PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and <ce:italic>cis</ce:italic>,<ce:italic>cis</ce:italic>-[{Ru(DMSO)Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-tppz)]·2Me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CO·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O have also been previously studied by our group . The work reported in this paper describes the synthesis and characterization of new mono and dinuclear tppz complexes of Rh(III) and Cd(II), [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>.acetylacetone and [{CdCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-tppz)].ethylene glycol. The only Cd(II)-tppz  and Rh(III)-tppz  crystal structures reported are that of [{Cd(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(MeOH)}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-tppz)] and [Rh<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(μ-O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CMe)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tppz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(MeOH)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>][PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>. There is no example of a crystal structure of a mononuclear complex of Rh(III)-tppz.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: At this point in time, seven coordination modes of metal complexes with tppz ligand are known . The tppz bridged bimetallic complexes [{CuCl}2(μ-tppz)][PF6]2 and cis,cis-[{Ru(DMSO)Cl2}2(μ-tppz)]⋅2Me2CO⋅2H2O have also been previously studied by our group . The work reported in this paper describes the synthesis and characterization of new mono and dinuclear tppz complexes of Rh(III) and Cd(II), [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF6]2.acetylacetone and [{CdCl2}2(μ-tppz)].ethylene glycol. The only Cd(II)-tppz  and Rh(III)-tppz  crystal structures reported are that of [{Cd(NO3)2(MeOH)}2(μ-tppz)] and [Rh4(μ-O2CMe)2(tppz)2(MeOH)4][PF6]4. There is no example of a crystal structure of a mononuclear complex of Rh(III)-tppz.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials and general methods

All reagents and solvents used were of reagent grade. Elemental analyses were performed by using a Heraeus CHN-O-Rapid elemental analyzer. FT-IR spectra were recorded as KBr pellets on a FT-IR JASCO 460 spectrophotometer and electronic spectra on a JASCO 7580 spectrophotometer. 1H NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker DRX-500MHz, Avance spectrometer at ambient temperature in DMSO-d6. Cyclic voltammograms were recorded by using a SAMA Research Analyzer M-500. Three electrodes were utilized in this system, a glassy carbon disk working electrode (  ϕ   5mm), a platinum wire auxiliary electrode and a Ag/AgCl reference electrode. The platinum disk working electrode was manually cleaned with 1-μm diamond polish prior to each scan. The supporting electrolyte, tetrabutylammonium hexafluorophosphate (TBAH), was twice recrystallized from ethanol-water (1/1) and vacuum-dried at 110°C overnight. DMSO was distilled over CaH2 and degassed under vacuum prior to use in the cyclic voltammetry. The solutions were deoxygenated by bubbling with Ar for 15min. The procedure was performed at room temperature and the Ar atmosphere was maintained over the solution during measurements. Ferrocene (E o =0.665V versus NHE, ΔE p =60mV) was used as an internal reference . The range of potential studied was between +1 and -2.2V.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Emission spectra were taken on a CARY ECLIPS spectrophotometer. The spectra were measured in DMSO solution at room temperature. Solutions were taken in a 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm path length fused silica cell. Absolute emission quantum yields (<ce:italic>Φ</ce:italic>) were determined by comparison of the integrated emission intensity with that of Rhodamine B under identical conditions. Rhodamine B solutions absorb in plastics and should be kept in glass. <ce:italic>Caution:</ce:italic> Rhodamine B is suspected to be carcinogenic.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Emission spectra were taken on a CARY ECLIPS spectrophotometer. The spectra were measured in DMSO solution at room temperature. Solutions were taken in a 1cm path length fused silica cell. Absolute emission quantum yields (Φ) were determined by comparison of the integrated emission intensity with that of Rhodamine B under identical conditions. Rhodamine B solutions absorb in plastics and should be kept in glass. Caution: Rhodamine B is suspected to be carcinogenic.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Synthesis of [{CdCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-tppz)].ethylene glycol</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">In a glass test tube, a solution of CdCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.04<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL 1:1 (V/V) ethanol/acetone was carefully layered on top of a solution of tppz (0.0388<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL chloroform using ethylene glycol (3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) as an interlayer. After 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>days at room temperature, colorless single-crystals suitable for X-ray crystallography appeared at the boundary, in a yield of 22%. <ce:italic>Anal</ce:italic>. Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">22</ce:inf>Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>: C, 38.21; H, 2.71; N, 10.28. Found: C, 38.55; H, 2.76; N, 10.39%. <ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>H NMR (<ce:italic>δ</ce:italic> ppm, 500<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>MHz, DMSO-d<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>, 298<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K): 8.57 (d, 4H), 8.09 (d, 4H), 7.84 (dd, 4H), 7.59 (dd, 4H).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [{CdCl2}2(μ-tppz)].ethylene glycol

In a glass test tube, a solution of CdCl2⋅H2O (0.04g, 0.2mmol) in 5mL 1:1 (V/V) ethanol/acetone was carefully layered on top of a solution of tppz (0.0388g, 0.1mmol) in 5mL chloroform using ethylene glycol (3mL) as an interlayer. After 5days at room temperature, colorless single-crystals suitable for X-ray crystallography appeared at the boundary, in a yield of 22%. Anal. Calc. for C26H22Cd2Cl4N6O2: C, 38.21; H, 2.71; N, 10.28. Found: C, 38.55; H, 2.76; N, 10.39%. 1H NMR (δ ppm, 500MHz, DMSO-d6, 298K): 8.57 (d, 4H), 8.09 (d, 4H), 7.84 (dd, 4H), 7.59 (dd, 4H).

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Synthesis of [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>.acetylacetone</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">A solution of tppz (0.37<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.95<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL ethanol was slowly added to a solution of RhCl<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>·<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.95<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in 25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL ethanol. The mixture was heated at reflux temperature for 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h while being stirred vigorously. Upon cooling, a fine brown–green powder product was precipitated and filtered out. The product was washed with cold ethanol followed by diethyl ether and air dried. The yield of [Rh(tppz)Cl<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>] was 0.493<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g (86.8%). elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF6]2.acetylacetone

A solution of tppz (0.37g, 0.95mmol) in 20mL ethanol was slowly added to a solution of RhCl3⋅xH2O (0.25g, 0.95mmol) in 25mL ethanol. The mixture was heated at reflux temperature for 5h while being stirred vigorously. Upon cooling, a fine brown-green powder product was precipitated and filtered out. The product was washed with cold ethanol followed by diethyl ether and air dried. The yield of [Rh(tppz)Cl3] was 0.493g (86.8%). A mixture of [Rh(tppz)Cl3] (0.298g, 0.5mmol) and 2,2'-bipyridine (0.078g, 0.5mmol) in 90mL 2:1 (V/V) ethanol/water was heated at reflux temperature for 1h. To the solution was then added AgNO3 (0.17g, 1mmol) and the resulting solution was stirred at reflux temperature for 1h. The solution was cooled to -5°C overnight and filtered through Celite to remove the fine white AgCl precipitate. The filtrate was evaporated to dryness on the rotary evaporator. The brown powdery residue was dissolved in 20mL water and precipitated from solution as a hexafluorophosphate salt by the addition of NH4PF6 (0.326g, 2mmol). The PF6 - counter ion increased the solubility of the complex in polar organic solvents and resulted in easier purification. The product, [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF6]2 was collected by suction filtration, washed with cold water and diethyl ether, and air dried. The crude product was purified by column chromatography (alumina, grade IV, weakly acidic, 150 mesh with column dimensions: height 50cm and diameter 3cm). Elution with 3:1 acetonitrile/toluene gave a yellow-green band, which was collected, evaporated to dryness, and then recrystallized by slow evaporation of a 1:1 acetonitrile/acetylacetone solution of the complex. After 4days at room temperature, yellow-green single-crystals suitable for X-ray crystallography were formed in a yield of 63%. Anal. Calc. for C39H32ClF12N8O2P2Rh: C, 43.65; H, 3.00; N, 10.44. Found: C, 43.94; H, 2.97; N, 10.60%. 1H NMR (δ ppm, 500MHz, DMSO-d6, 298K): 10.11 (d, 1H), 9.80 (d, 1H), 9.69 (1H, d), 9.56 (d, 1H), 8.78 (dd, 1H), 8.64 (d, 2H), 8.33 (dd, 1H), 8.16 (dd, 1H), 8.21 (d, 2H), 8.07 (d, 2H), 7.94 (dd, 2H), 7.83 (dd, 2H), 7.56 (dd, 1H), 7.45 (d, 2H), 7.30 (m, 4H).

elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallography

The colorless crystals of [{CdCl2}2(μ-tppz)].ethylene glycol were grown at the boundary of a Cd(II) solution in acetone/ethanol (1:1V/V) and a tppz solution in CHCl3 in the presence of ethylene glycol as an interlayer solvent. The yellow-green crystals of [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF6]2.acetylacetone were grown by the slow evaporation of a 1:1 acetonitrile/acetylacetone solution of the complex. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction measurements of the complexes were carried out on a Bruker Apex II, using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ =0.71073Å) at 120(2)K. Unit cell parameters were determined by the least-squares calculations with θ angles ranging from 2.06° to 28.99° for [{CdCl2}2(μ-tppz)].ethylene glycol and 1.47° to 25.99° for [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF6]2.acetylacetone.

All hydrogen atoms were located from the difference Fourier syntheses and placed in geometrically calculated positions. All hydrogen atom positions were refined in an isotropic approximation in the riding model with the U iso(H) parameters equal to 1.5 U eq(Ci) for methyl groups and 1.2 U eq(Ci) for other carbon atoms, where U(Ci) are the equivalent thermal parameters of the atoms to which corresponding H atoms are bonded. All calculations were performed on an IBM PC/AT using the shelxtl version 5.1 software , giving a final R 1 =0.0278, WR 2 =0.0690 (for 3392 reflections with I >2σ(I)) for [{CdCl2}2(μ-tppz)].ethylene glycol and R 1 =0.0478, WR 2 =0.1076 (for 6030 reflections with I >2σ(I)) for [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF6]2 acetyl acetone. The largest diffraction peak and hole on the final difference- Fourier map were 1.238 and -0.622eÅ-3 for [{CdCl2}2(μ-tppz)].ethylene glycol and 1.719 and -0.479eÅ-3 for [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF6]2.acetylacetone. Further details of the structural analyses are given in  .

elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

The selected bond lengths and angles of complexes [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF6]2 and [{CdCl2}2(μ-tppz)] are listed in   , respectively.

There are three general classes of structures that arise from the tridentate-coordination mode of the tppz ligand, including the [M(tppz)], [M(tppz)2], and [M2(μ-tppz)] structures. The simplest of these are the [M(tppz)] structures that involve coordination of one mono-tridentate tppz to a single metal, leaving the other side free . This binding mode is observed for the mononuclear Rh(III) complex [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF6]2.   shows the coordination geometry of the ligands about the Rh(III) ion. A distorted octahedral coordination at Rh(III) is defined by the N donor atoms of a tppz ligand bound in a κ-N(3),N(4),N(5) mode with the N(3) and N(5) atoms trans to each other, the N donor atoms of a bpy ligand and one Cl- anion. The N(2) atom of the bpy ligand is trans to Cl-.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The pyridyl rings of the uncoordinated tppz molecule are planar within experimental errors, but the tppz ligand as a whole is far from being planar due to the steric effects between the hydrogen atoms on the 3-pyridyl positions. Low energy conformations of tppz are predicted to have each pyridyl ring twisted from coplanarity with the pyrazine by roughly 50° . For the tppz ligand, the dihedral angle between the mean planes of the two coordinated pyridyl rings is 3.97° whereas that between the two uncoordinated pyridyl rings is 48.92°. It deserves to be noted that the free N(6) and N(8) pyridyl nitrogen atoms are up and down from the pyrazine ring. It seems that the weak hydrogen bonds involving N(6)⋯H(12A) (2.523<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) and N(8)⋯H(23A) (2.535<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) occur in the structure of [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>. The pyridyl rings of bpy ligand are nearly coplanar, with a dihedral angle between the mean planes of 2.68°.</ce:para>

Low energy conformations of tppz are predicted to have each pyridyl ring twisted from coplanarity with the pyrazine by roughly 50° . For the tppz ligand, the dihedral angle between the mean planes of the two coordinated pyridyl rings is 3.97° whereas that between the two uncoordinated pyridyl rings is 48.92°. It deserves to be noted that the free N(6) and N(8) pyridyl nitrogen atoms are up and down from the pyrazine ring. It seems that the weak hydrogen bonds involving N(6)⋯H(12A) (2.523Å) and N(8)⋯H(23A) (2.535Å) occur in the structure of [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF6]2. The pyridyl rings of bpy ligand are nearly coplanar, with a dihedral angle between the mean planes of 2.68°.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The bite angles are defined as N–Rh–N angles involving the nitrogen atoms of a tppz or bpy ligand. The ideal bite angles for a tridentate ligand in an octahedral environment would be 90° and 180°. The Rh–tppz bite angles are less than the ideal angles at 81.10°, 80.79° and 161.87°. The ideal bite angle for bpy in an octahedral coordination geometry is 90°. The Rh–bpy bite angle (N(2)–Rh(1)–N(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>80.14°) is less than 90°.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The bite angles are defined as N-Rh-N angles involving the nitrogen atoms of a tppz or bpy ligand. The ideal bite angles for a tridentate ligand in an octahedral environment would be 90° and 180°. The Rh-tppz bite angles are less than the ideal angles at 81.10°, 80.79° and 161.87°. The ideal bite angle for bpy in an octahedral coordination geometry is 90°. The Rh-bpy bite angle (N(2)-Rh(1)-N(1)=80.14°) is less than 90°.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The shortness of the Rh–N(pyrazine) bond compared with the Rh–N(pyridine) bonds () is suggested to be due to the stronger π-accepting properties of the pyrazine ring. Crystallography revealed one acetylacetone molecule (enol form) per complex [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> in the crystal structure. This solvent of crystallization has an intramolecular hydrogen bond between the O atom of the carbonyl group and the enolic H atom (O(2)–H(2)⋯O(1), d(H⋯O)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.65<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). In the keto–enol tautomerism, the enol form is usually unstable, does not survive long, and changes into the keto form. This is because the oxygen is more electronegative than carbon and thus forms stronger multiple bonds. Hence, a carbon–oxygen (carbonyl) double bond is more than twice as strong as a carbon–oxygen single bond, but a carbon–carbon double bond is weaker than two carbon–carbon single bonds. 1,3-Diketones, such as acetylacetone, are particularly prone to form stable enols or enolates because of conjugation of the enol or enolate with the other carbonyl group and the stability gained in forming a six-membered ring (hydrogen bonded in the case of the enol or containing the counter ion in the case of the enolate).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The shortness of the Rh-N(pyrazine) bond compared with the Rh-N(pyridine) bonds () is suggested to be due to the stronger π-accepting properties of the pyrazine ring. Crystallography revealed one acetylacetone molecule (enol form) per complex [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF6]2 in the crystal structure. This solvent of crystallization has an intramolecular hydrogen bond between the O atom of the carbonyl group and the enolic H atom (O(2)-H(2)⋯O(1), d(H⋯O)=1.65Å). In the keto-enol tautomerism, the enol form is usually unstable, does not survive long, and changes into the keto form. This is because the oxygen is more electronegative than carbon and thus forms stronger multiple bonds. Hence, a carbon-oxygen (carbonyl) double bond is more than twice as strong as a carbon-oxygen single bond, but a carbon-carbon double bond is weaker than two carbon-carbon single bonds. 1,3-Diketones, such as acetylacetone, are particularly prone to form stable enols or enolates because of conjugation of the enol or enolate with the other carbonyl group and the stability gained in forming a six-membered ring (hydrogen bonded in the case of the enol or containing the counter ion in the case of the enolate).

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The literature reveals many crystal structures of the [M<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-tppz)] binding mode . The major significance of these complexes is that they can serve as precursors for mixed valence complexes. The binding mode [M<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-tppz)] is observed for the dinuclear Cd(II) complex [{CdCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-tppz)] (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>). The Cd(II) compound is a neutral and centrosymmetric dinuclear complex in which the tppz ligand functions in a bis-tridentate bridging manner to link two Cd(II) ions that are separated by 7.286<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. Each Cd(II) center is five-coordinated by three N donor atoms of tppz in one plane and two Cl<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ions normal to this plane; the Cl–Cd(II)–Cl angle is 101.72(3)°. The molecular structures of five-coordinate transition metal complexes show an extensive range from regular trigonal bipyramidal (RTBP) to regular square-based pyramidal (RSBP). The structure index parameter, <ce:italic>τ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>(<ce:italic>β</ce:italic>−<ce:italic>α</ce:italic>/60), was evaluated by the two large angles (<ce:italic>α</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp><<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>β</ce:italic>) in the five-coordinated geometry, where <ce:italic>τ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.0 for a RTBP geometry and <ce:italic>τ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.0 for a RSBP . The coordination geometry around Cd(II) is slightly distorted from regular square-based pyramidal, as ascertained by the observed <ce:italic>τ</ce:italic> value of 0.20. One Cl<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> and three nitrogen atoms of the tppz ligand constitute the basal plane of the square pyramid, and the remaining Cl<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> occupies the apical position (). The Cd<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>–N(pyrazine) distance is very slightly longer than the Cd<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>–N(pyridyl) distances. The π-accepting property of tppz is saturated by two Cd(II) metal centers, leading to the longer distance. The Cd<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>–Cl distances of 2.4492(8) and 2.5161(7)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å compare well with the reported Cd<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>–Cl distances . However, if one accepts weak intermolecular Cd⋯Cl (1−<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, 1/2−<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>) interactions of 3.0431(8)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, the coordination geometry can be described as being based on an octahedron (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>). The Cd⋯Cl weak coordination leads to the formation of a 1D chain in the solid state (). The Cd(1)⋯Cd(1B) distance through the two bridging chloride ligands is 4.211<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The two Cd(II) ions are, respectively, below and above the plane of the pyrazine moiety of the bridging tppz ligand. This conformation probably minimizes steric strain while at the same time maximizes the bonding interaction of the tppz ligand with the Cd(II) ions. The dihedral angle between the mean planes of the two coordinated pyridyl rings is 44.83°. The dihedral angles between the pyrazine ring and each of the pyridyl rings are 36.19° (C(2)–C(6)/N(1)) and 34.42° (C(10)–C(14)/N(15)). Unlike the bidentate complexes of tppz, the two pyridine rings of most tridentate tppz complexes do not bow out of the pyrazine ring plane. Instead, the pyrazine ring twists to push one pyridine ring up and the other ring down. The two pyridine rings then rotate in the opposite direction to bring their lone pairs close to the metal ion .

In the crystal, hydrogen bonds between the complex and ethylene glycol solvate molecules are presented (O(1S)–H(1S)⋯Cl(1)).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The literature reveals many crystal structures of the [M2(μ-tppz)] binding mode . The major significance of these complexes is that they can serve as precursors for mixed valence complexes. The binding mode [M2(μ-tppz)] is observed for the dinuclear Cd(II) complex [{CdCl2}2(μ-tppz)] ( ). The Cd(II) compound is a neutral and centrosymmetric dinuclear complex in which the tppz ligand functions in a bis-tridentate bridging manner to link two Cd(II) ions that are separated by 7.286Å. Each Cd(II) center is five-coordinated by three N donor atoms of tppz in one plane and two Cl- ions normal to this plane; the Cl-Cd(II)-Cl angle is 101.72(3)°. The molecular structures of five-coordinate transition metal complexes show an extensive range from regular trigonal bipyramidal (RTBP) to regular square-based pyramidal (RSBP). The structure index parameter, τ =(β-α/60), was evaluated by the two large angles (α < β) in the five-coordinated geometry, where τ =1.0 for a RTBP geometry and τ =0.0 for a RSBP . The coordination geometry around Cd(II) is slightly distorted from regular square-based pyramidal, as ascertained by the observed τ value of 0.20. One Cl- and three nitrogen atoms of the tppz ligand constitute the basal plane of the square pyramid, and the remaining Cl- occupies the apical position (). The CdII-N(pyrazine) distance is very slightly longer than the CdII-N(pyridyl) distances. The π-accepting property of tppz is saturated by two Cd(II) metal centers, leading to the longer distance. The CdII-Cl distances of 2.4492(8) and 2.5161(7)Å compare well with the reported CdII-Cl distances . However, if one accepts weak intermolecular Cd⋯Cl (1-x, y, 1/2-z) interactions of 3.0431(8)Å, the coordination geometry can be described as being based on an octahedron ( ). The Cd⋯Cl weak coordination leads to the formation of a 1D chain in the solid state (). The Cd(1)⋯Cd(1B) distance through the two bridging chloride ligands is 4.211Å. The two Cd(II) ions are, respectively, below and above the plane of the pyrazine moiety of the bridging tppz ligand. This conformation probably minimizes steric strain while at the same time maximizes the bonding interaction of the tppz ligand with the Cd(II) ions. The dihedral angle between the mean planes of the two coordinated pyridyl rings is 44.83°. The dihedral angles between the pyrazine ring and each of the pyridyl rings are 36.19° (C(2)-C(6)/N(1)) and 34.42° (C(10)-C(14)/N(15)). Unlike the bidentate complexes of tppz, the two pyridine rings of most tridentate tppz complexes do not bow out of the pyrazine ring plane. Instead, the pyrazine ring twists to push one pyridine ring up and the other ring down. The two pyridine rings then rotate in the opposite direction to bring their lone pairs close to the metal ion .   shows the fragment of crystal packing (projection along the b crystal axis) of [{CdCl2}2(μ-tppz)].ethylene glycol. In the crystal, hydrogen bonds between the complex and ethylene glycol solvate molecules are presented (O(1S)-H(1S)⋯Cl(1)).

elements.clean_text: Data for the infrared spectra for tppz, and the mono and bimetallic complexes were obtained as solids in KBr. Predominant vibrations for the free tppz ligand are associated with ν(CC), ν(CN) and ring stretching. The reported separation between ν(CC) and ν(CN) is close to 20cm-1 for polypyridyl ligands , and thus the observed vibrational absorption bands for tppz at 1592 and 1567cm-1 may be due to either different ν(CN) on the pyrazine and pyridine rings or ν(CC) and ν(CN) with coincidental equivalence of the different rings . An intense band at 1393cm-1 is assigned to ring stretching of both the pyrazine and pyridine rings of tppz. The FT-IR spectrum of [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF6]2 shows a absorption pattern in the 4000-400cm-1 region similar to the bpy and tppz ligands. A strong band at 1617cm-1 is assigned to ν(CO) of the acetylacetone. The strong absorption band at 841cm-1 is assigned to ν(P-F) and demonstrates the existence of PF6 - as a counter ion .

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The results obtained from the <ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>H NMR spectra support the structures obtained from the X-ray analysis and suggest that the structures of the complexes [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and [{CdCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-tppz)] are retained in DMSO-d<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> solution. The NMR assignment for the mixed ligand complex [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> is aided by integration values and comparison to the known systems bpy, tppz, [Ru(L)(tppz)Cl]ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> (L<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2,2′-dipyridylamine) , [Ru(tppz)(4,4′-(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)bpy)Cl]PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>
, [Ru(dpk)(tppz)Cl][ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] (dpk<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2,2′-dipyridylketone)  and [Ru(tpy)(tppz)][PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (tpy<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2,2′:6′,2″-terpyridine) . Metal-free tppz shows four well-resolved <ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>H NMR signals (8.05, 7.80, 7.23 and 8.38<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm) at room temperature . In the <ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>H NMR spectrum of [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> in DMSO-d<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>, the bpy protons are non-equivalent as one ring is <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic> to Cl and one ring is <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic> to the pyrazine nitrogen of tppz. Therefore, the protons on each ring of bpy are non-equivalent and integrate with relative value (1). The non-equivalency for the tppz protons arises from the coordination of one end of the ligand to Rh(III), with the subsequent upfield shift of the resonances produced by an increase in electronic density due to π-backbonding. The resonances of the uncoordinated tppz rings shift downfield, as observed for similar complexes .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The results obtained from the 1H NMR spectra support the structures obtained from the X-ray analysis and suggest that the structures of the complexes [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF6]2 and [{CdCl2}2(μ-tppz)] are retained in DMSO-d6 solution. The NMR assignment for the mixed ligand complex [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF6]2 is aided by integration values and comparison to the known systems bpy, tppz, [Ru(L)(tppz)Cl]ClO4 (L=2,2'-dipyridylamine) , [Ru(tppz)(4,4'-(CH3)bpy)Cl]PF6 , [Ru(dpk)(tppz)Cl][ClO4] (dpk=2,2'-dipyridylketone)  and [Ru(tpy)(tppz)][PF6]2 (tpy=2,2':6',2"-terpyridine) . Metal-free tppz shows four well-resolved 1H NMR signals (8.05, 7.80, 7.23 and 8.38ppm) at room temperature . In the 1H NMR spectrum of [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF6]2 in DMSO-d6, the bpy protons are non-equivalent as one ring is trans to Cl and one ring is trans to the pyrazine nitrogen of tppz. Therefore, the protons on each ring of bpy are non-equivalent and integrate with relative value (1). The non-equivalency for the tppz protons arises from the coordination of one end of the ligand to Rh(III), with the subsequent upfield shift of the resonances produced by an increase in electronic density due to π-backbonding. The resonances of the uncoordinated tppz rings shift downfield, as observed for similar complexes .

elements.clean_text: The electronic absorption spectroscopy of [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF6]2 was found to be quite complicated due to the many possible transitions. It is possible to have tppz π→π∗ and n →π∗ transitions as well as ligand field (LF) (t 2g 6 → e g), MLCT (Rh→tppz and/or Rh→bpy) and LMCT (Cl→Rh) transitions. The electronic absorption spectroscopy of 4d6 and 5d6 complexes with polypyridyl ligands is characterized by intense ligand π→π∗ and n →π∗ transitions in the ultraviolet region and metal (dπ)→ligand (π∗) charge transfer (MLCT) transitions in the visible region . In general only the first spin-allowed LF band of Rh(III) complexes may be observed, the second band frequently being obscured by the CT absorption . The electronic spectrum of [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF6]2 was taken in DMSO ( ). The intense absorption bands at 272 and 322nm most likely arise from the spin-allowed ligand-centered (LC) (π→π∗) transitions. The absorption band (shoulder) at about 355nm is assigned as the dπ(Rh)→π∗(tppz) charge transfer transition (MLCT) on the basis of the assignments of mononuclear tppz complexes of Ir(III), Rh(III), Ru(II) and Os(II) , while the weak shoulder at about 398nm is most likely a LF transition.

elements.clean_text:
The absorption spectrum of [{CdCl2}2(μ-tppz)] in DMSO ( ) displayed a band at 277nm. This intense band is assigned to a LC (π→π∗) transition.

A representative cyclic voltammogram of [{CdCl2}2(μ-tppz)] at a glassy carbon electrode is given in  . The voltammetric response of this complex shows an irreversible wave at -1.175V which can be attributed to cadmium reduction process, since cadmium(II) nitrate shows a peak at -0.67V. Upon formation of a tppz bridged dinuclear complex, the bridging tppz becomes easier to reduce due to stabilization of the π∗ orbital induced by the coordination of the second electron deficient metal center. For example, in [Ru(tpy)(tppz)]2+ (tpy=2,2':6',2"-terpyridine), two reduction couples of tppz (tppz0/- and tppz-/2-) were observed at -0.97 and 1.60V, while in [(tpy)Ru(μ-tppz)Ru(tpy)]4+, two reduction couples of tppz were recorded at -0.35 and -0.84V . In a neutral complex [{CdCl2}2(μ-tppz)], the tppz0/- and tppz-/2- couples were observed at -1.58 and -1.88V, respectively.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The cyclic voltammogram of [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> is shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig8"></ce:float-anchor>. The electrochemical behavior of [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> is characterized by metal based and ligand based reductions. The first irreversible two-electron reduction (−0.71<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>V) is assigned as Rh(III/I), the second and third reductions (−1.11 and −1.67<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>V) are assigned as tppz<ce:sup loc="post">0/−</ce:sup> and tppz<ce:sup loc="post">−/2−</ce:sup>, and the fourth reduction (−1.96<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>V) is assigned as bpy<ce:sup loc="post">0/−</ce:sup>. The tppz<ce:sup loc="post">0/−</ce:sup> and tppz<ce:sup loc="post">−/2−</ce:sup> couples occur prior to the bpy<ce:sup loc="post">0/−</ce:sup> reduction due to the larger π system of tppz ligand as a result of the two extra pyridyl rings on tppz as well as the extra electron accepting character of the pyrazine ring. Tppz has a substantially lower energy π<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup> orbital than bpy. The two-electron reduction of Rh(III) therefore results in accumulation of an electron on the metal center and destabilizes the complex. This can rationalize the “electron-transfer chemical-reaction (EC)” process, in which the chemical reaction involves loss of a chloride ion, which proceeds and leads to the irreversible process at the first reduction wave. In <ce:italic>cis</ce:italic>-[Rh(bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>X<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> (X<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Cl<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>, Br<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>, and I<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>), the irreversible Rh(III/I) couple was observed at a negative potential . The electrochemistry reported for the [Rh<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>(SacSac)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>] (SacSac<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>dithioacetylacetone) complex indicates a structural instability associated with reduction of this species, consistent with the expectation for addition of the electron into a d<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">σ</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>-type (d<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup>) orbital .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The cyclic voltammogram of [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF6]2 is shown in  . The electrochemical behavior of [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF6]2 is characterized by metal based and ligand based reductions. The first irreversible two-electron reduction (-0.71V) is assigned as Rh(III/I), the second and third reductions (-1.11 and -1.67V) are assigned as tppz0/- and tppz-/2-, and the fourth reduction (-1.96V) is assigned as bpy0/-. The tppz0/- and tppz-/2- couples occur prior to the bpy0/- reduction due to the larger π system of tppz ligand as a result of the two extra pyridyl rings on tppz as well as the extra electron accepting character of the pyrazine ring. Tppz has a substantially lower energy π∗ orbital than bpy. The two-electron reduction of Rh(III) therefore results in accumulation of an electron on the metal center and destabilizes the complex. This can rationalize the "electron-transfer chemical-reaction (EC)" process, in which the chemical reaction involves loss of a chloride ion, which proceeds and leads to the irreversible process at the first reduction wave. In cis-[Rh(bpy)2X2]+ (X=Cl-, Br-, and I-), the irreversible Rh(III/I) couple was observed at a negative potential . The electrochemistry reported for the [RhIII(SacSac)3] (SacSac=dithioacetylacetone) complex indicates a structural instability associated with reduction of this species, consistent with the expectation for addition of the electron into a d σ -type (d∗) orbital .

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The photoluminescence properties of both complexes were studied at room temperature in DMSO solution. Because of the low solubility of the complexes, we have been forced to study the spectral and emission measurements in DMSO solution. Since tppz itself hardly fluoresces, the fluorescence of the tppz complexes may result from the change in the lowest excited state from the <ce:italic>n</ce:italic>,π<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup> triplet to the π,π<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup> singlet, which becomes lower in energy than the <ce:italic>n</ce:italic>,π<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup> triplet due to the complexation with the metal ion as a strong Lewis acid . In the absence of metal ions, the fluorescence of the ligand is probably quenched by the occurrence of a photoinduced electron transfer (PET) process due to the presence of lone pairs of electrons of the donor atoms in the ligand. PET is an electron transfer which occurs when certain photoactive materials interact with light. The fluorescent emission of [{CdCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-tppz)] at the excitation wavelength of 277<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm is shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig9"></ce:float-anchor>. Although CdCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> is not luminescent, interestingly many cadmium coordination complexes containing polypyridyl ligands show an intense fluorescence band upon excitation at the ligand’s absorption band in solution as well as in the solid state. No emissions originating from metal-centered and MLCT or LMCT excited states are expected for the Cd(II) complexes, since the Cd(II) ion is difficult to oxidize or reduce due to its d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> configuration . Thus, the emission observed at 406<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (<ce:italic>Φ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.29) in [{CdCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-tppz)] is tentatively assigned to the <ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>(π–π<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup>) intraligand fluorescence.</ce:para>

Because of the low solubility of the complexes, we have been forced to study the spectral and emission measurements in DMSO solution. Since tppz itself hardly fluoresces, the fluorescence of the tppz complexes may result from the change in the lowest excited state from the n,π∗ triplet to the π,π∗ singlet, which becomes lower in energy than the n,π∗ triplet due to the complexation with the metal ion as a strong Lewis acid . In the absence of metal ions, the fluorescence of the ligand is probably quenched by the occurrence of a photoinduced electron transfer (PET) process due to the presence of lone pairs of electrons of the donor atoms in the ligand. PET is an electron transfer which occurs when certain photoactive materials interact with light. The fluorescent emission of [{CdCl2}2(μ-tppz)] at the excitation wavelength of 277nm is shown in  . Although CdCl2 is not luminescent, interestingly many cadmium coordination complexes containing polypyridyl ligands show an intense fluorescence band upon excitation at the ligand's absorption band in solution as well as in the solid state. No emissions originating from metal-centered and MLCT or LMCT excited states are expected for the Cd(II) complexes, since the Cd(II) ion is difficult to oxidize or reduce due to its d10 configuration . Thus, the emission observed at 406nm (Φ =0.29) in [{CdCl2}2(μ-tppz)] is tentatively assigned to the 1(π-π∗) intraligand fluorescence.

elements.clean_text: The emission spectrum of a deoxygenated solution of [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF6]2 at the excitation wavelength of 322nm is shown in  . The maximum emission peak of this complex is located at 435nm (Φ =8×10-3). Since electrochemical data indicated that the reduction orbital of the metal center is d∗, instead of π∗ in nature, participating luminescence, the following emission in [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF6]2 can thus be ruled out: metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT), sigma-bond-to-ligand charge transfer (SBLCT), halide-to-ligand charge transfer (XLCT), ligand-to-ligand charge transfer (LLCT) or ligand-centered (LC) emission . This conclusion in turn supports the πd∗ emission assignment at room temperature. For the complexes cis-[Rh(bpy)(DPA)Cl2] and cis-[Rh(phen)(DPA)Cl2] (DPA=the deprotonated form of 2,2'-dipyridylamine), only a one-electron reduction process occurs at the metal with elimination of a Cl- anion. Based on the luminescence and electrochemical data, the emission of these complexes was assigned as πd∗ . Some pseudo-octahedral Rh(III) complexes which contain the ortho-metallated phenylpyridine anion as a ligand are phosphorescent at room temperature .

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">In this study, two tppz complexes, [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>.acetylacetone and [{CdCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-tppz)].ethylene glycol, have been synthesized and characterized.</ce:para><ce:para view="all">Luminescent polynuclear d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> metal complexes such as Cd(II) are of great interest because of their potential application in chemical optical sensors, photosensitization and electroluminescent devices. It is interesting that the dinuclear complex [{CdCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-tppz)] has a very strong emission band centered at 406<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm upon excitation at 277<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm. Metal ions can enhance or quench the fluorescence emission of polypyridyl ligands. Quenching of fluorescence of a ligand by transition metal ions during complexation is a rather common phenomenon which is explained by processes such as magnetic perturbation, redox activity and electronic energy transfer. Enhancement of fluorescence through complexation is, however, of much interest as it opens up the opportunity for photochemical applications of these complexes . The fluorescent intensity of the dinuclear Cd(II) complex is significantly stronger than that of free tppz, probably due to the conformational rigidity enhancement of the coordinated tppz, thereby reducing the non-radiative decay of the intraligand <ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>(π–π<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup>) excited state. Thus, [{CdCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-tppz)] may be used as an advanced material for light emitting diode devices and may be an excellent candidate for solvent-resistance fluorescent material because it is almost insoluble in most common solvents such as methanol, ethanol, acetone, CHCl<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and water.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In this study, two tppz complexes, [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF6]2.acetylacetone and [{CdCl2}2(μ-tppz)].ethylene glycol, have been synthesized and characterized.

Luminescent polynuclear d10 metal complexes such as Cd(II) are of great interest because of their potential application in chemical optical sensors, photosensitization and electroluminescent devices. It is interesting that the dinuclear complex [{CdCl2}2(μ-tppz)] has a very strong emission band centered at 406nm upon excitation at 277nm. Metal ions can enhance or quench the fluorescence emission of polypyridyl ligands. Quenching of fluorescence of a ligand by transition metal ions during complexation is a rather common phenomenon which is explained by processes such as magnetic perturbation, redox activity and electronic energy transfer. Enhancement of fluorescence through complexation is, however, of much interest as it opens up the opportunity for photochemical applications of these complexes . The fluorescent intensity of the dinuclear Cd(II) complex is significantly stronger than that of free tppz, probably due to the conformational rigidity enhancement of the coordinated tppz, thereby reducing the non-radiative decay of the intraligand 1(π-π∗) excited state. Thus, [{CdCl2}2(μ-tppz)] may be used as an advanced material for light emitting diode devices and may be an excellent candidate for solvent-resistance fluorescent material because it is almost insoluble in most common solvents such as methanol, ethanol, acetone, CHCl3, CH2Cl2 and water.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Rhodium (III) complexes have played a central role in the understanding of the electrochemical, photochemical and photophysical processes of d<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup> complexes. The mononuclear Rh(III) complex, [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, shows only an irreversible two-electron reduction process at the metal center with elimination of chloride. At room temperature, this complex shows a blue emission, assigned as πd<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup> phosphorescence. The electrochemical data also provide evidence in support of the assigned πd<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup> emission of the complex. In summary, [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> is an example for the rational design of a transition metal complex which under ambient conditions exhibits a phosphorescence at relatively short wavelength.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Rhodium (III) complexes have played a central role in the understanding of the electrochemical, photochemical and photophysical processes of d6 complexes. The mononuclear Rh(III) complex, [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF6]2, shows only an irreversible two-electron reduction process at the metal center with elimination of chloride. At room temperature, this complex shows a blue emission, assigned as πd∗ phosphorescence. The electrochemical data also provide evidence in support of the assigned πd∗ emission of the complex. In summary, [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF6]2 is an example for the rational design of a transition metal complex which under ambient conditions exhibits a phosphorescence at relatively short wavelength.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [{CdCl2}2(μ-tppz)].ethylene glycol

In a glass test tube, a solution of CdCl2⋅H2O (0.04g, 0.2mmol) in 5mL 1:1 (V/V) ethanol/acetone was carefully layered on top of a solution of tppz (0.0388g, 0.1mmol) in 5mL chloroform using ethylene glycol (3mL) as an interlayer. After 5days at room temperature, colorless single-crystals suitable for X-ray crystallography appeared at the boundary, in a yield of 22%. Anal. Calc. for C26H22Cd2Cl4N6O2: C, 38.21; H, 2.71; N, 10.28. Found: C, 38.55; H, 2.76; N, 10.39%. 1H NMR (δ ppm, 500MHz, DMSO-d6, 298K): 8.57 (d, 4H), 8.09 (d, 4H), 7.84 (dd, 4H), 7.59 (dd, 4H).

Synthesis of [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF6]2.acetylacetone

A solution of tppz (0.37g, 0.95mmol) in 20mL ethanol was slowly added to a solution of RhCl3⋅xH2O (0.25g, 0.95mmol) in 25mL ethanol. The mixture was heated at reflux temperature for 5h while being stirred vigorously. Upon cooling, a fine brown-green powder product was precipitated and filtered out. The product was washed with cold ethanol followed by diethyl ether and air dried. The yield of [Rh(tppz)Cl3] was 0.493g (86.8%). A mixture of [Rh(tppz)Cl3] (0.298g, 0.5mmol) and 2,2'-bipyridine (0.078g, 0.5mmol) in 90mL 2:1 (V/V) ethanol/water was heated at reflux temperature for 1h. To the solution was then added AgNO3 (0.17g, 1mmol) and the resulting solution was stirred at reflux temperature for 1h. The solution was cooled to -5°C overnight and filtered through Celite to remove the fine white AgCl precipitate. The filtrate was evaporated to dryness on the rotary evaporator. The brown powdery residue was dissolved in 20mL water and precipitated from solution as a hexafluorophosphate salt by the addition of NH4PF6 (0.326g, 2mmol). The PF6 - counter ion increased the solubility of the complex in polar organic solvents and resulted in easier purification. The product, [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF6]2 was collected by suction filtration, washed with cold water and diethyl ether, and air dried. The crude product was purified by column chromatography (alumina, grade IV, weakly acidic, 150 mesh with column dimensions: height 50cm and diameter 3cm). Elution with 3:1 acetonitrile/toluene gave a yellow-green band, which was collected, evaporated to dryness, and then recrystallized by slow evaporation of a 1:1 acetonitrile/acetylacetone solution of the complex. After 4days at room temperature, yellow-green single-crystals suitable for X-ray crystallography were formed in a yield of 63%. Anal. Calc. for C39H32ClF12N8O2P2Rh: C, 43.65; H, 3.00; N, 10.44. Found: C, 43.94; H, 2.97; N, 10.60%. 1H NMR (δ ppm, 500MHz, DMSO-d6, 298K): 10.11 (d, 1H), 9.80 (d, 1H), 9.69 (1H, d), 9.56 (d, 1H), 8.78 (dd, 1H), 8.64 (d, 2H), 8.33 (dd, 1H), 8.16 (dd, 1H), 8.21 (d, 2H), 8.07 (d, 2H), 7.94 (dd, 2H), 7.83 (dd, 2H), 7.56 (dd, 1H), 7.45 (d, 2H), 7.30 (m, 4H).

The structures were solved by direct method and refined by full-matrix least-squares against F 2 in anisotropic (for non-hydrogen atoms) approximation. All hydrogen atoms were located from the difference Fourier syntheses and placed in geometrically calculated positions. All hydrogen atom positions were refined in an isotropic approximation in the riding model with the U iso(H) parameters equal to 1.5 U eq(Ci) for methyl groups and 1.2 U eq(Ci) for other carbon atoms, where U(Ci) are the equivalent thermal parameters of the atoms to which corresponding H atoms are bonded. All calculations were performed on an IBM PC/AT using the shelxtl version 5.1 software , giving a final R 1 =0.0278, WR 2 =0.0690 (for 3392 reflections with I >2σ(I)) for [{CdCl2}2(μ-tppz)].ethylene glycol and R 1 =0.0478, WR 2 =0.1076 (for 6030 reflections with I >2σ(I)) for [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF6]2 acetyl acetone. The largest diffraction peak and hole on the final difference- Fourier map were 1.238 and -0.622eÅ-3 for [{CdCl2}2(μ-tppz)].ethylene glycol and 1.719 and -0.479eÅ-3 for [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF6]2.acetylacetone. Further details of the structural analyses are given in  .

The RhIII-Cl bond length of 2.3258(10)Å is larger than the Rh-N distances. The RhIII-Cl distance compares well with the reported RhIII-Cl distances . The RhIII-Cl bond length is shorter than the average RuII-Cl bond length that was derived from the cis,cis-[{Ru(DMSO)Cl2}2(μ-tppz)]⋅2Me2CO⋅2H2O structure . The shorter RhIII-Cl distance indicates significant σ bonding in this bond. A π donation from the Cl- ligand to Rh(III) is not possible because of its d6 (t 2g 6) electron configuration.  also shows two PF6 - counter ions. The P-F bond lengths range from 1.578 (4) to 1.604(3)Å, with an average of 1.596(8)Å. The lattice structure is further stabilized by a network of weak hydrogen bonds between the H atoms of the acetylacetone or pyridyl rings of the tppz ligand and the F atoms of the PF6 - anions, with C-H⋯F distances of 2.409-3.950Å.

The literature reveals many crystal structures of the [M2(μ-tppz)] binding mode . The major significance of these complexes is that they can serve as precursors for mixed valence complexes. The binding mode [M2(μ-tppz)] is observed for the dinuclear Cd(II) complex [{CdCl2}2(μ-tppz)] ( ). The Cd(II) compound is a neutral and centrosymmetric dinuclear complex in which the tppz ligand functions in a bis-tridentate bridging manner to link two Cd(II) ions that are separated by 7.286Å. Each Cd(II) center is five-coordinated by three N donor atoms of tppz in one plane and two Cl- ions normal to this plane; the Cl-Cd(II)-Cl angle is 101.72(3)°. The molecular structures of five-coordinate transition metal complexes show an extensive range from regular trigonal bipyramidal (RTBP) to regular square-based pyramidal (RSBP). The structure index parameter, τ =(β-α/60), was evaluated by the two large angles (α < β) in the five-coordinated geometry, where τ =1.0 for a RTBP geometry and τ =0.0 for a RSBP . The coordination geometry around Cd(II) is slightly distorted from regular square-based pyramidal, as ascertained by the observed τ value of 0.20. One Cl- and three nitrogen atoms of the tppz ligand constitute the basal plane of the square pyramid, and the remaining Cl- occupies the apical position (). The CdII-N(pyrazine) distance is very slightly longer than the CdII-N(pyridyl) distances. The π-accepting property of tppz is saturated by two Cd(II) metal centers, leading to the longer distance. The CdII-Cl distances of 2.4492(8) and 2.5161(7)Å compare well with the reported CdII-Cl distances . However, if one accepts weak intermolecular Cd⋯Cl (1-x, y, 1/2-z) interactions of 3.0431(8)Å, the coordination geometry can be described as being based on an octahedron ( ). The Cd⋯Cl weak coordination leads to the formation of a 1D chain in the solid state (). The Cd(1)⋯Cd(1B) distance through the two bridging chloride ligands is 4.211Å. The two Cd(II) ions are, respectively, below and above the plane of the pyrazine moiety of the bridging tppz ligand. This conformation probably minimizes steric strain while at the same time maximizes the bonding interaction of the tppz ligand with the Cd(II) ions. The dihedral angle between the mean planes of the two coordinated pyridyl rings is 44.83°. The dihedral angles between the pyrazine ring and each of the pyridyl rings are 36.19° (C(2)-C(6)/N(1)) and 34.42° (C(10)-C(14)/N(15)). Unlike the bidentate complexes of tppz, the two pyridine rings of most tridentate tppz complexes do not bow out of the pyrazine ring plane. Instead, the pyrazine ring twists to push one pyridine ring up and the other ring down. The two pyridine rings then rotate in the opposite direction to bring their lone pairs close to the metal ion .   shows the fragment of crystal packing (projection along the b crystal axis) of [{CdCl2}2(μ-tppz)].ethylene glycol. In the crystal, hydrogen bonds between the complex and ethylene glycol solvate molecules are presented (O(1S)-H(1S)⋯Cl(1)).

The electronic absorption spectroscopy of [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF6]2 was found to be quite complicated due to the many possible transitions. It is possible to have tppz π→π∗ and n →π∗ transitions as well as ligand field (LF) (t 2g 6 → e g), MLCT (Rh→tppz and/or Rh→bpy) and LMCT (Cl→Rh) transitions. The electronic absorption spectroscopy of 4d6 and 5d6 complexes with polypyridyl ligands is characterized by intense ligand π→π∗ and n →π∗ transitions in the ultraviolet region and metal (dπ)→ligand (π∗) charge transfer (MLCT) transitions in the visible region . In general only the first spin-allowed LF band of Rh(III) complexes may be observed, the second band frequently being obscured by the CT absorption . The electronic spectrum of [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF6]2 was taken in DMSO ( ). The intense absorption bands at 272 and 322nm most likely arise from the spin-allowed ligand-centered (LC) (π→π∗) transitions. The absorption band (shoulder) at about 355nm is assigned as the dπ(Rh)→π∗(tppz) charge transfer transition (MLCT) on the basis of the assignments of mononuclear tppz complexes of Ir(III), Rh(III), Ru(II) and Os(II) , while the weak shoulder at about 398nm is most likely a LF transition.

<ce:para view="all">The absorption spectrum of [{CdCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-tppz)] in DMSO (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig6"></ce:float-anchor>) displayed a band at 277<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm. This intense band is assigned to a LC (π<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>π<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup>) transition.</ce:para><ce:para view="all">A representative cyclic voltammogram of [{CdCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-tppz)] at a glassy carbon electrode is given in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig7"></ce:float-anchor>. The voltammetric response of this complex shows an irreversible wave at −1.175<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>V which can be attributed to cadmium reduction process, since cadmium(II) nitrate shows a peak at −0.67<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>V. Upon formation of a tppz bridged dinuclear complex, the bridging tppz becomes easier to reduce due to stabilization of the π<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup> orbital induced by the coordination of the second electron deficient metal center. For example, in [Ru(tpy)(tppz)]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> (tpy<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2,2′:6′,2″-terpyridine), two reduction couples of tppz (tppz<ce:sup loc="post">0/−</ce:sup> and tppz<ce:sup loc="post">−/2−</ce:sup>) were observed at −0.97 and 1.60<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>V, while in [(tpy)Ru(μ-tppz)Ru(tpy)]<ce:sup loc="post">4+</ce:sup>, two reduction couples of tppz were recorded at −0.35 and −0.84<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>V . In a neutral complex [{CdCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-tppz)], the tppz<ce:sup loc="post">0/−</ce:sup> and tppz<ce:sup loc="post">−/2−</ce:sup> couples were observed at −1.58 and −1.88<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>V, respectively.</ce:para><ce:para view="all">The cyclic voltammogram of [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> is shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig8"></ce:float-anchor>. The electrochemical behavior of [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> is characterized by metal based and ligand based reductions. The first irreversible two-electron reduction (−0.71<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>V) is assigned as Rh(III/I), the second and third reductions (−1.11 and −1.67<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>V) are assigned as tppz<ce:sup loc="post">0/−</ce:sup> and tppz<ce:sup loc="post">−/2−</ce:sup>, and the fourth reduction (−1.96<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>V) is assigned as bpy<ce:sup loc="post">0/−</ce:sup>. The tppz<ce:sup loc="post">0/−</ce:sup> and tppz<ce:sup loc="post">−/2−</ce:sup> couples occur prior to the bpy<ce:sup loc="post">0/−</ce:sup> reduction due to the larger π system of tppz ligand as a result of the two extra pyridyl rings on tppz as well as the extra electron accepting character of the pyrazine ring. Tppz has a substantially lower energy π<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup> orbital than bpy. The two-electron reduction of Rh(III) therefore results in accumulation of an electron on the metal center and destabilizes the complex. This can rationalize the “electron-transfer chemical-reaction (EC)” process, in which the chemical reaction involves loss of a chloride ion, which proceeds and leads to the irreversible process at the first reduction wave. In <ce:italic>cis</ce:italic>-[Rh(bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>X<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> (X<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Cl<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>, Br<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>, and I<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>), the irreversible Rh(III/I) couple was observed at a negative potential . The electrochemistry reported for the [Rh<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>(SacSac)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>] (SacSac<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>dithioacetylacetone) complex indicates a structural instability associated with reduction of this species, consistent with the expectation for addition of the electron into a d<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">σ</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>-type (d<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup>) orbital .</ce:para><ce:para view="all">The photoluminescence properties of both complexes were studied at room temperature in DMSO solution. Because of the low solubility of the complexes, we have been forced to study the spectral and emission measurements in DMSO solution. Since tppz itself hardly fluoresces, the fluorescence of the tppz complexes may result from the change in the lowest excited state from the <ce:italic>n</ce:italic>,π<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup> triplet to the π,π<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup> singlet, which becomes lower in energy than the <ce:italic>n</ce:italic>,π<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup> triplet due to the complexation with the metal ion as a strong Lewis acid . In the absence of metal ions, the fluorescence of the ligand is probably quenched by the occurrence of a photoinduced electron transfer (PET) process due to the presence of lone pairs of electrons of the donor atoms in the ligand. PET is an electron transfer which occurs when certain photoactive materials interact with light. The fluorescent emission of [{CdCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-tppz)] at the excitation wavelength of 277<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm is shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig9"></ce:float-anchor>. Although CdCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> is not luminescent, interestingly many cadmium coordination complexes containing polypyridyl ligands show an intense fluorescence band upon excitation at the ligand’s absorption band in solution as well as in the solid state. No emissions originating from metal-centered and MLCT or LMCT excited states are expected for the Cd(II) complexes, since the Cd(II) ion is difficult to oxidize or reduce due to its d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> configuration . Thus, the emission observed at 406<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (<ce:italic>Φ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.29) in [{CdCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-tppz)] is tentatively assigned to the <ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>(π–π<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup>) intraligand fluorescence.</ce:para><ce:para view="all">The emission spectrum of a deoxygenated solution of [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> at the excitation wavelength of 322<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm is shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig10"></ce:float-anchor>. The maximum emission peak of this complex is located at 435<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (<ce:italic>Φ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">−3</ce:sup>). Since electrochemical data indicated that the reduction orbital of the metal center is d<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup>, instead of π<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup> in nature, participating luminescence, the following emission in [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> can thus be ruled out: metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT), sigma-bond-to-ligand charge transfer (SBLCT), halide-to-ligand charge transfer (XLCT), ligand-to-ligand charge transfer (LLCT) or ligand-centered (LC) emission . This conclusion in turn supports the πd<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup> emission assignment at room temperature. For the complexes <ce:italic>cis</ce:italic>-[Rh(bpy)(DPA)Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] and <ce:italic>cis</ce:italic>-[Rh(phen)(DPA)Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (DPA<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>the deprotonated form of 2,2′-dipyridylamine), only a one-electron reduction process occurs at the metal with elimination of a Cl<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anion. Based on the luminescence and electrochemical data, the emission of these complexes was assigned as πd<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup>
. Some pseudo-octahedral Rh(III) complexes which contain the <ce:italic>ortho</ce:italic>-metallated phenylpyridine anion as a ligand are phosphorescent at room temperature .</ce:para><ce:section-title>Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">In this study, two tppz complexes, [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>.acetylacetone and [{CdCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-tppz)].ethylene glycol, have been synthesized and characterized.</ce:para><ce:para view="all">Luminescent polynuclear d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> metal complexes such as Cd(II) are of great interest because of their potential application in chemical optical sensors, photosensitization and electroluminescent devices. It is interesting that the dinuclear complex [{CdCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-tppz)] has a very strong emission band centered at 406<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm upon excitation at 277<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm. Metal ions can enhance or quench the fluorescence emission of polypyridyl ligands. Quenching of fluorescence of a ligand by transition metal ions during complexation is a rather common phenomenon which is explained by processes such as magnetic perturbation, redox activity and electronic energy transfer. Enhancement of fluorescence through complexation is, however, of much interest as it opens up the opportunity for photochemical applications of these complexes . The fluorescent intensity of the dinuclear Cd(II) complex is significantly stronger than that of free tppz, probably due to the conformational rigidity enhancement of the coordinated tppz, thereby reducing the non-radiative decay of the intraligand <ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>(π–π<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup>) excited state. Thus, [{CdCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-tppz)] may be used as an advanced material for light emitting diode devices and may be an excellent candidate for solvent-resistance fluorescent material because it is almost insoluble in most common solvents such as methanol, ethanol, acetone, CHCl<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and water.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
The absorption spectrum of [{CdCl2}2(μ-tppz)] in DMSO ( ) displayed a band at 277nm. This intense band is assigned to a LC (π→π∗) transition.

A representative cyclic voltammogram of [{CdCl2}2(μ-tppz)] at a glassy carbon electrode is given in  . The voltammetric response of this complex shows an irreversible wave at -1.175V which can be attributed to cadmium reduction process, since cadmium(II) nitrate shows a peak at -0.67V. Upon formation of a tppz bridged dinuclear complex, the bridging tppz becomes easier to reduce due to stabilization of the π∗ orbital induced by the coordination of the second electron deficient metal center. For example, in [Ru(tpy)(tppz)]2+ (tpy=2,2':6',2"-terpyridine), two reduction couples of tppz (tppz0/- and tppz-/2-) were observed at -0.97 and 1.60V, while in [(tpy)Ru(μ-tppz)Ru(tpy)]4+, two reduction couples of tppz were recorded at -0.35 and -0.84V . In a neutral complex [{CdCl2}2(μ-tppz)], the tppz0/- and tppz-/2- couples were observed at -1.58 and -1.88V, respectively.

The cyclic voltammogram of [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF6]2 is shown in  . The electrochemical behavior of [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF6]2 is characterized by metal based and ligand based reductions. The first irreversible two-electron reduction (-0.71V) is assigned as Rh(III/I), the second and third reductions (-1.11 and -1.67V) are assigned as tppz0/- and tppz-/2-, and the fourth reduction (-1.96V) is assigned as bpy0/-. The tppz0/- and tppz-/2- couples occur prior to the bpy0/- reduction due to the larger π system of tppz ligand as a result of the two extra pyridyl rings on tppz as well as the extra electron accepting character of the pyrazine ring. Tppz has a substantially lower energy π∗ orbital than bpy. The two-electron reduction of Rh(III) therefore results in accumulation of an electron on the metal center and destabilizes the complex. This can rationalize the "electron-transfer chemical-reaction (EC)" process, in which the chemical reaction involves loss of a chloride ion, which proceeds and leads to the irreversible process at the first reduction wave. In cis-[Rh(bpy)2X2]+ (X=Cl-, Br-, and I-), the irreversible Rh(III/I) couple was observed at a negative potential . The electrochemistry reported for the [RhIII(SacSac)3] (SacSac=dithioacetylacetone) complex indicates a structural instability associated with reduction of this species, consistent with the expectation for addition of the electron into a d σ -type (d∗) orbital .

The photoluminescence properties of both complexes were studied at room temperature in DMSO solution. Because of the low solubility of the complexes, we have been forced to study the spectral and emission measurements in DMSO solution. Since tppz itself hardly fluoresces, the fluorescence of the tppz complexes may result from the change in the lowest excited state from the n,π∗ triplet to the π,π∗ singlet, which becomes lower in energy than the n,π∗ triplet due to the complexation with the metal ion as a strong Lewis acid . In the absence of metal ions, the fluorescence of the ligand is probably quenched by the occurrence of a photoinduced electron transfer (PET) process due to the presence of lone pairs of electrons of the donor atoms in the ligand. PET is an electron transfer which occurs when certain photoactive materials interact with light. The fluorescent emission of [{CdCl2}2(μ-tppz)] at the excitation wavelength of 277nm is shown in  . Although CdCl2 is not luminescent, interestingly many cadmium coordination complexes containing polypyridyl ligands show an intense fluorescence band upon excitation at the ligand's absorption band in solution as well as in the solid state. No emissions originating from metal-centered and MLCT or LMCT excited states are expected for the Cd(II) complexes, since the Cd(II) ion is difficult to oxidize or reduce due to its d10 configuration . Thus, the emission observed at 406nm (Φ =0.29) in [{CdCl2}2(μ-tppz)] is tentatively assigned to the 1(π-π∗) intraligand fluorescence.

The emission spectrum of a deoxygenated solution of [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF6]2 at the excitation wavelength of 322nm is shown in  . The maximum emission peak of this complex is located at 435nm (Φ =8×10-3). Since electrochemical data indicated that the reduction orbital of the metal center is d∗, instead of π∗ in nature, participating luminescence, the following emission in [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF6]2 can thus be ruled out: metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT), sigma-bond-to-ligand charge transfer (SBLCT), halide-to-ligand charge transfer (XLCT), ligand-to-ligand charge transfer (LLCT) or ligand-centered (LC) emission . This conclusion in turn supports the πd∗ emission assignment at room temperature. For the complexes cis-[Rh(bpy)(DPA)Cl2] and cis-[Rh(phen)(DPA)Cl2] (DPA=the deprotonated form of 2,2'-dipyridylamine), only a one-electron reduction process occurs at the metal with elimination of a Cl- anion. Based on the luminescence and electrochemical data, the emission of these complexes was assigned as πd∗ . Some pseudo-octahedral Rh(III) complexes which contain the ortho-metallated phenylpyridine anion as a ligand are phosphorescent at room temperature .

Conclusion

In this study, two tppz complexes, [Rh(tppz)(bpy)Cl][PF6]2.acetylacetone and [{CdCl2}2(μ-tppz)].ethylene glycol, have been synthesized and characterized.

Luminescent polynuclear d10 metal complexes such as Cd(II) are of great interest because of their potential application in chemical optical sensors, photosensitization and electroluminescent devices. It is interesting that the dinuclear complex [{CdCl2}2(μ-tppz)] has a very strong emission band centered at 406nm upon excitation at 277nm. Metal ions can enhance or quench the fluorescence emission of polypyridyl ligands. Quenching of fluorescence of a ligand by transition metal ions during complexation is a rather common phenomenon which is explained by processes such as magnetic perturbation, redox activity and electronic energy transfer. Enhancement of fluorescence through complexation is, however, of much interest as it opens up the opportunity for photochemical applications of these complexes . The fluorescent intensity of the dinuclear Cd(II) complex is significantly stronger than that of free tppz, probably due to the conformational rigidity enhancement of the coordinated tppz, thereby reducing the non-radiative decay of the intraligand 1(π-π∗) excited state. Thus, [{CdCl2}2(μ-tppz)] may be used as an advanced material for light emitting diode devices and may be an excellent candidate for solvent-resistance fluorescent material because it is almost insoluble in most common solvents such as methanol, ethanol, acetone, CHCl3, CH2Cl2 and water.
